title: latest telethon shows us once and for all that c4s just a load of cake and balls
story: You watch BBC’s Children In Need, you’re getting Clare Balding, Doctor Who and dancers, whether you like it or not.ITV  It’d take sniper fire or a dinner setting next to Sir Phillip Green before Cowell was a no-show.Channel , though Apart from a bit of a secondhand cake-baking and Gogglebox, I was drawing a blank before Friday night.So it was with a mix of fascination and dread that I tuned into Stand Up To Cancer. A seven-hour slog live from Westminster City Hall, presented by Adam Hills, Maya Jama and the network’s spare part Alan Carr, who set the tone for most of what followed interviewing Foxy from SAS: Who Dares Wins.“It’s been announced you’ve got a new Stand Up To Cancer series starting next year. Tell us about it.”“I can’t.”“Give us some names.”“I can’t.”No sooner had we written that one off than it become apparent there was no Bake Off special either — just a promo for a show that will be screened months from now. No matter, though. With its lofty public-serving hat on, Adam Hills faithfully promised Channel  would “educate, entertain and inspire” us for the remainder of the evening, which must have looked quite good written down.In practice The first thing to say about Stand Up To Cancer is that it featured some of the most beautul and affecting films you’ll see on a telethon.They needed to be, as well, ’cos you don’t have to have watched the event to know it contained a lot of feeble stunts and sketches.I also could have lived without Adam Hills carrying out a threat to have his pubic hair waxed, live, once the total reached £million, and the educational segment, with Katherine Ryan and Chris O’Dowd, which was sunk the moment he announced: “We’re goingto put the humour in tumour.”Tellingly, there was also a fair bit of non-network talent involved, including James Corden.I’ll not dwell, though, on what Channel ’s Twitter feed did to the Carpool Karaoke segment, where Michael Buble talked about his son’s illness, except to say it was one of those productions where the left hand wasn’t talking to the right.So when Chris O’Dowd was moved to tears talking about the cancer films, the studio audience was guffawing loudly at Alan Carr manoeuvring himself into background position in a Prue Leith wig.By a process of elimination and production gaffs, though, it became apparent the centre of Channel ’s entire universe now is Gogglebox, which had created an all-star version with Louis Tomlinson, Danny Dyer and daughter Dani for the occasion.They missed a trick, frankly, by not capturing Louis falling asleep to The X Factor. But it was still riotously funny watching the regulars pick apart Naked Attraction, with the choicest comment being: “That one looks like Homer Simpson’s mouth.”This was not the sound of people laughing with the channel, though. They were laughing at it.A network that was once known for being brave and innovative is now far more readily associated with a genital parade, third-rate reality shows and cakes than anything in the way of ground-breaking drama or comedy.In fact, the only two genuinely funny people on its payroll are probably Jimmy Carr and Sean Lock, who had to make way, at Stand Up To Cancer, for box-ticking randoms like Mo Gilligan, who was served this testicular curve-ball by Maya Jama.“Do you have a special name for your balls, by any chance ”He does.The Big Narstie Show.So there I was, gently drting off as Darcey Bussell went through the technical motions on Strictly. “The control in the rise and fall. Strong in the two-three.”When, unless I’m imagining it, she told Sean Walsh: “You have to smooth it out and iron it out, so it isn’t jerking off or skippy.”Suddenly I was all ears for the show’s Halloween special – an event which, for three good reasons, is usually my least favourite of the run.Firstly, Tess always expects a laugh for referring to it as a “spook-tacular”. Secondly, someone does The ****ing Timewarp. And thirdly, the worst danceris forced to jig around to The Monster Mash.We got it all, on Saturday night, of course, yet somehow it didn’t feel quite such an endurance as normal.This may have been partly down to Ashley Roberts and Faye Tozer, who both danced like dreams, but it definitely owed something to the presence of Sean, who’s added real jeopardy to proceedings andactual comedy.His snog with Katya has made sense of a dreadful line-up and the BBC should be eternally grateful to The Sun and the photographer for capturing the moment.So although the handbag-clutchers will no doubt disagree, I was genuinely sad to see him voted off and probably back to the ex-girlfriend, where, in the words of Darcey Bussell, he’ll have to “smooth it out and iron it out” or he’ll end up, you know . . . “skippy”.Sandra Oh’s performance in Killing Eve. Aberdeen clinically dispatching some Glasgow-based team - in the Betfred Cup semi-final on Sunday.Nabhaan Rizwan heading towards the awards zone with BBC’s Informer, the best show currently on television.And the one positive to emerge from Luisa Omielan’s Politics For Bitches, which was the response from an estate agent when the “comedian” asked him what she’d have to do to afford a multi-million-pound mansion in London’s Little Venice.“Be funnier.”Since the last quarterly update, EastEnders has split into two distinct and very contrasting shows. There’s a brutal, gripping and addictive version set in Mick Carter’s prison wing, which seemed to have vanished into thin air a couple of weeks ago.And there’s the other, more familiar EastEnders we’re stuck with full-time now. A loud, grim and unforgiving place where Hayley Slater cannot decide between calling her unborn baby Stacey, in tribute to her cousin Jean, as a nod to the mad auntie, or Lee Marvin in honour of Big Mo.Worse still, though, is -year-old Keanu’s ongoing, very energetic affair with mighty Sharon Mitchell, , who’s attempted to cover the truth by claiming he’s her “personal trainer”. .“I gave him his job back,” she claimed, “He’s been getting me in shape.” The shape of what, though, is the question  An oval  A rhomboid Guy the Gorilla’s statue at London zoo An unflattering image, admittedly, but it’s nothing compared to the mental one Dot Cotton conjured up on Tuesday night, with readers of a fragile disposition advised to look away now: “Don’t play the innocent with me, Robbie Jackson. title: suzy lamplugh cops search for remains
story: The property in Sutton Coldfield, West Mids, is the former home of the mother of prime suspect John Cannan. Suzy, , was abducted in  and declared dead, presumed murdered, in .It follows information that Cannan may have buried -year-old Suzy there after abducting and murdering her.Excavation work was focusing on an old corrugated iron garage in the back garden of the semi- detached property in Sutton Coldfield, West Mids.A forensic tent was also placed over an area of concrete patio.Suzy disappeared after going to meet a client named “Mr Kipper” to show him two houses in Fulham, South West London in July .Her body has never been found, though she was declared dead — presumed murdered — in .It remains one of Britain’s most infamous unsolved murders.But cold case review detectives now suspect that after murdering Suzy, Cannan may have driven to what was then his mother’s home.They fear he put Suzy’s body in an inspection pit in the garage he used for working on cars, before filling it with concrete.The corrugated iron structure was yesterday dismantled by Met Police specialist search cops to enable excavation work to start.Ground-penetrating radar was used to scan the area and a tent was erected where the garage stood.The team of about a dozen officers had shovels and garden forks on hand for digging.A side entrance to the garden via a small private track, was cordoned off at around am as the search team arrived in eight police vans.Officers conducted the grim search just a few feet from a children’s trampoline and a swing.The importance of the search is enhanced by Cannan’s habit of ing to his mother’s home after committing serious crimes.It is believed that his mother Sheila is in her s and living in a dferent part of the country.There is no suggestion that she was involved in or had any knowledge of this or any of his crimes.The search at her former home is expected to go on for several days. A forensic archaeologist is guiding cops during the search.It is being carried out with the full consent of a family who have lived there since Cannan’s mother moved out in .The cold case review team is not conducting a full-scale investigation into Suzy’s abduction and murder but are said to be acting on specic information relating to the potential burial site.A source said: “The couple who lived there were shocked when the police came to them asking to search their garden.“But they have given their full consent to the search.“Police have already conducted a cursory examination there and established that everything fits with what they were told.”Cannan, now , is serving a minimum  years in Full Sutton prison for the murder of Shirley Banks in .Information was first received in December  from one of Cannan’s fellow prisoners, that Suzy was buried under the patio at his mother’s house.The inmate came forward after police took the highly unusual step of naming Cannan as their prime suspect when the CPS ruled there was insufficient information to charge him with Suzy’s murder.Cannan is serving three le sentences for murdering newlywed Shirley in Bristol in October , attempting to kidnap a woman the previous evening and raping another woman at knepoint in Reading, Berks, a year earlier.The suspected serial killer was captured three weeks after Shirley, , vanished, when he robbed a dress shop assistant at knepoint in Leamington Spa, Warwicks.A road tax disc from Shirley’s car was found in the glove box of Cannan’s black BMW. It led to the discovery of her Mini Clubman in his garage at a block of flats where he lived in Clton, Bristol.The Mini had the  number plate SLP S — suspected of being a reference to Suzy’s name.Cannan was given a whole le sentence at Exeter crown court in April , but it was commuted on appeal to a -year minimum tarf, meaning he is eligible to apply for parole in four years.Ex-car salesman Cannan is also a leading suspect in the murder of Bournemouth insurance worker Sandra Court, , whose body was found in a water-filled ditch after she was abducted in May .Despite a wealth of circumstantial evidence in Suzy’s murder pointing towards Cannan, the case against him has been undermined by a lack of forensic evidence and a body.Three major searches for Suzy were conducted in the early s and in .The first two focused on a former barracks site in Worcestershire.Then in  a field near the barracks was searched, along with a Quantock Hills earthwork site in Somerset known as Dead Woman’s Ditch, where Shirley’s body was found in .The Met Police said last night: “The search follows information received in relation to a historical unsolved investigation.“We will not be commenting on speculation surrounding the search, or providing any further information at this time.”THE search at the former home of John Cannan’s mother comes too late for Suzy’s parents.Her solicitor father Paul died in June this year aged  after a long battle with Parkinson’s disease. Her mother Diana, , died in .Following their daughter’s disappearance, the Lamplughs, of East Sheen, South West London, set up the Suzy Lamplugh Trust to promote safety of women in memory of their daughter.They campaigned for better taxi safety and laws protecting victims of stalking.The couple, who have three other children, Richard, Tamsin and Lizzie who were both awarded the OBE in .They were convinced of Cannan’s guilt.Mr Lamplugh spoke out after the  decision by the CPS not to prosecute.He said: “Suzy was a lovely girl and we and her brother and sisters and her many friends still miss her enormously.“It’s greatly distressing that Suzy’s body has not been found nor do we know how she was killed.“The least the offender can do now is tell us where the body is.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: fedex delivery worker louisiana finds baby crawling truck
story: The unsupervised child was spotted by FedEx employee Byron Nash as he pulled up to the property in Lake Charles, Louisiana, on Friday.He posted video of the shocking encounter to Facebook, saying: “This baby was crawling outside under my truck after my truck was parked to make a delivery, luckily I seen her before I backed out. No supervision in sight.”The child is seen clearly in the footage, dwarfed by the huge wheels of Byron’s truck, as she stares up at him innocently.While filming the close-call, the astonished driver is heard saying: “This baby is right under my truck and her parents arent nowhere to be found! Look at this, this baby is outside by herself.”The caring driver then swoops down to pick up the child, as well as the package, and heads towards the family home to confront the parents.He is met by a woman who is supposed to have been minding the child, and is gobsmacked to learn she had no idea the child had crawled outside.Byron is seen approaching the entrance of the property through the garage, where he finds an open door.He shouts through: “Hello! title: philip hammond budget cash public money
story: Philip Hammond spoke yesterday for more than an hour. There were announcements on schools funding, defence, moving “from disposable to reusable cups across all beverage types” — even a tax break for public loos. More money for social care and Universal Credit.Shopkeepers will breathe a sigh of relief at a hefty cut to business rates.There were hints of more money for the police. Sun readers will also welcome the tax freezes on beer, spirits, cider and short-haul flights.But the big bucks — some £.billion of the £.billion extra the Government expects to spend come - — went to the NHS, fulfilling the Prime Minister’s summer promise to increase spending as a th birthday present to a health service creaking under the strain of an ageing population.The question, of course, was how the Chancellor was going to pay for it.Before the Budget, all sorts of grim possibilities had been floated.Extra taxes on white-van men, lower- ing the VAT threshold and tightening the rules about National Insurance contributions. Taxes on plastic cups . Taxes on pretty much anything, really.Perhaps the best thing the Chancellor did in his Budget, then, was say “No”.To almost all of it. For an hour or more, I waited for the sting in the tail — the bit where Fiscal Phil turned Hatchet Hammond.But it never came. In paying for his promises — and above all, the NHS — the Chancellor was helped by better-than-expected borrowing forecasts, which showed our economy’s remarkable record of creating jobs is still going strong.But he has also made a calculation that it is better to live with a small and manageable deficit than try to drag the finances back into surplus at the cost of higher taxes. And that voters will see through Labour’s promises to hike borrowing back to stratospheric levels in the name of a socialist transformation of the economy.He decided, in other words, people pay enough tax already.And he’s right. All too often in recent years, it has felt like the answer to every problem — at least from Whitehall’s point of view — is higher taxes and more interference.Hammond was never going to copy his tax-slashing Tory predecessor Nigel Lawson, who made it a point of principle to abolish a dferent tax with every Budget.But at least he drew a line in the sand, deciding it is better when hardworking people get to keep more of their own money.That ending austerity should not, and must not, mean higher tax bills. That hard work should mean hard cash in your pocket.Yes, Hammond — like every Chancellor since Gordon Brown — made too many fiddly little announcements.But he avoided the kind of whacking- great raid on taxpayers’ pockets so many were urging him towards.This doesn’t mean we are out of the woods. Britain’s growth prospects over the next half-decade are still extraordinarily sluggish.The outcome of the Brexit deal will drastically change the fiscal picture.In many ways, Hammond’s speech yesterday was a holding action ahead of the much bigger decisions to come.We still need much more radical action to kickstart growth and productivity. Despite the scale of the housing crisis, for example, there was only tinkering around the edges.But a large part of delivering that growth must involve making the economy more dynamic, more competitive and letting people keep more of their own money as a reward for their efforts — moving the country in the direction outlined by Philip Hammond, rather than the one sketched out by Jeremy Corbyn .The overall verdict on the Budget  The jokes were worse than expected but the numbers were better.More spending on the NHS, tax cuts for millions of voters and the worst ideas kept out of it.Yes, borrowing will be higher — but low enough to keep us out of the danger zone and far, far lower than under a Corbyn government.That is a menu Philip Hammond will be pretty happy with.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Three quarters of the Chancellor’s vast increase in cash to ministries will go to the NHS, to pay for its £bn a year boost announced by Theresa May last summer.But Treasury officials insisted even after health’s new money pile, there would still be inflation-linked rises for every department in next year’s Whitehall-wide spending review.Dubbing his Budget “a defining moment in this long hard journey”, Mr Hammond told MPs: “The era of austerity is finally coming to an end”.The massive splurge sparked critics’ fears that he would lose control of the deficit again.But Mr Hammond title: meghan markle prince harry auckland welly wanging
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex braved the rain in Auckland as they near the end of their tour Down Under.The Royal pair went head-to-head to hurl gumboots at a target, along with kids from the Trees in Survival group.They were pictured laughing as the Duchess stepped up to lob her pink and white polka dot welly, while Harry threw a blue boot.And it was the Duchesss team who won on the day - the PM gave birth to baby Neve in June - but that she admired the duchess for her work while pregnant.She said: Its just increased my respect for the role that shes playing at such an often tiring time.I have real empathy and I think shes incredible.Earlier today Meghan got her hands dirty, helped to plant a kowhai tree - title: fascists rally mussolini hometown predappio
story: Far-right militants have gathered in Predappio to mark Il Duce’s rise to power with the March on Rome.Around , blackshirts gathered in the Italian capital to demand the resignation of the then Prime Minister Luigi Facta on the night of October  to , .In the rally to mark this march, many can be seen giving the fascist salute, which is not outlawed in the country despite its past.In one image a group of men give a right-arm salute while holding a banner of Mussolini.Another picture shows a woman dressed in a baseball cap and t-shirt with the word “Auschwitzland” and an outline of the death camp on it.In a third a man appears to be dressed in a black World War II-era military unorm.The far right militants in Italy have been encouraged due to the country’s sht to the right with the rise of the populist, Eurosceptic and anti-immigration Five Star Movement and its blocking of a parliamentary bill which was aimed at banning fascist salutes and the sale of Mussolini memorabilia.Earlier this year the party, lead by Luigi Di Maio, became the largest single party in the countrys parliament.It secured . percent of the vote and  seats, not enough to secure an overall majority though and the party is largely dependent on the Lega Nord for support.Thousands travel to Mussolini’s birthplace every year and souvenir shops sell fascist-themed souvenirs like coffee mugs that have the slogans: Believe, Obey and Fight.Born on July , , Mussolini was the leader of the country’s Partito Nazionale Fascista– PNF.He became Prime Minister in  after the March on Rome and effectively became a dictator in  and ruled until .Mussolini became known as Il Duce .Initially Mussolini had joined the Socialist Partybut was expelled for supporting military intervention in the First World War.After the war his views focused on “revolutionary nationalism”.Following the Abyssinia Crisis in - he invaded Ethiopia which was widely condemned by the Western Powers but he got the backing of Germany’s leader Adolf Hitler.Hitler and Mussolini formed what was called the Rome-Berlin Axis and signed a treaty of co-operation.On June ,  Italy joined the Second World War, on the side of Germany.In October that year Mussolini sent Italian forces into Greece although it was unsuccessful and the counter-offensive pushed the forces back to Albania.Italy also suffered a humiliating defeat when it joined with Germany in launching an attack on the Soviet Union.Mussolini also suffered a defeat when the Axis Powers were crushed in North Africa..In July  the Grand Council of Fascism passed a motion of no confidence in Mussolini and on July  the king dismissed him as head of the government.He was held in custody until he was rescued by German troops.Mussolini then tried to flee the country with his mistress Clara Petacci to Switzerland but both were captured by communist partisans and executed by firing squad.His body was then taken to Milan was it was hung upside down at a petrol station to publicly confirm his death.The far-right Forza Nuova party had announced a march called the “March of Patriots” in Rome for October  but the Interior Minister Marco Minniti said any march would be illegal.Speaking in parliament in September he said that any event like that “clearly recall[ed] the birth of the fascist regime and would clearly contrast with the legal order.In response to the initial criticism, Forza Nuovas leader Roberto Fiore denied any fascist or nostalgic element to the march, and called it a walk for security.

title: philip hammond facebook amazon google
story: The Chancellor said it wasn’t fair that companies such as Facebook were making so much in the UK but paying so little to the Treasury.The new ‘Digital Services Tax’ will see the so-called ‘Faangs’ – Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix and Google – taxed two per cent on the revenue they make from advertising and online marketplaces from April .Critics said it defied belief that the UK had set its rate at two per cent rather than the three per cent mooted by the European Union.Spain earlier this month proposed a three per cent rate when unveiling its own proposals to get tough with web companies and streaming services.The actual taxable revenue will also be based on ‘self-assessment’ by the companies.But the Chancellor insisted Britain was leading the way by moving now.Sources claimed an EU-wide tax was unlikely because Germany is fiercely opposed to the move.Speaking in the Commons Mr Hammond said: “Digital s pose a real challenge for the“The rules have simply not kept pace with changing business models.“And it’s clearly not sustainable, or fair, that digital  businesses can generate substantial value in the UK without paying tax here in respect of that business.”He added: “A new global agreement is the best long-term solution, but progress is painful slow. We cannot simply talk forever so we will now introduce a UK Digital Services Tax.”Aides admitted the UK was “treading softly” to start with but was “committed to action”.The move came as the Chancellor separately raided big business in general by taking away the employment allowance from all-but small firms to raise £ million. Entrepreneur’s relief will also be modied to limit the scope for tax avoidance.The Treasury’s independent forecasters estimate that only around  tech giants at most will be hit by the Digital Services Tax.It will only cover web firms generating more than £ million a year in global revenue – so as to spare tech start-ups and growing businesses.Mr Hammond made clear he didn’t want to introduce a general online sales tax on companies flogging goods directly to the public over the web.The ‘Digital Services Tax’ will instead focus on taxing the money made by the likes of Facebook from advertising to UK customers using a search engine or selling to another user via on “online marketplace”.The Chancellor unveiled his intention to get tough with web giants at Tory party conference earlier this month.Within days, Facebook was branded “immoral” after it revealed it had paid just £. million in tax in the UK last year despite sales of more than £. billion.The company declined to comment yesterday before seeing the detail.Internet giants have sparked outrage by channelling sales via countries such as Ireland and Luxembourg which have light-touch tax regimes.Business chiefs urged the Chancellor the new tax was “high risk”.CBI director general Carolyn Fairbairn said: “The Government should move in step internationally, leading multilateral solutions, or risk losing our global competitive edge in digital.”But Labour deputy leader and Shadow Culture Secretary Tom Watson said the raid was generating a “pittance”. He stormed: “The new tax isn’t even set to be implemented until  at which time the tech giants will start to enjoy a  per cent cut in their corporation tax rate. The lack of ambition in this announcement is just derisory.”Spain’s Finance Ministry unveiled its plans for a Digital Services Tax earlier this month – saying it wanted to also include giants such as Uber and Airbnb.Facebook Spain reported losses of £, recently.Finance Minister Maria Jesus Montero stormed: “There are businesses we all know that are dedicated to services and are generating billions in economic activity, yet do not pay appropriate taxes.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: after years of grim penny pinching budgets we must say nice one chancellor
story: Like the bumper tax cut for million workers, a year earlier than promised.The £billion NHS injection, the £billion bailout for defence, hundreds of millions for our pock-marked roads and hard-up schools. Another £.billion to iron out Universal Credit problems. A near five per cent hike in the minimum wage. A big, welcome cut in business rates for struggling firms.New ideas flowed: a levy on web giants’ UK revenues, potentially raising £million, is long overdue — though Philip Hammond must ensure the ­burden does not fall on online shoppers.There was major funding to help councils transform our hollowed-out High Streets, including turning vacant shops into homes. A huge increase in firms’ annual investment allowance will let them deduct from taxable profits up to £million spent on tools and machinery.Heathrow’s e-gates will now speed up entry for visitors from the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Japan as well as Europe — a symbol of a global Britain open for business.Some bad ideas The Sun has criticised, including the proposed “latte levy” on plastic cups, were binned. Duty was frozen again on fuel, as well as beer.Even the OBR’s normally pessimistic forecasts were on Mr Hammond’s side. Growth is predicted to rise steadily, albeit too slowly. Unemployment is set to fall to its lowest in  years.We wish the Chancellor had outlined more radical, visionary low-tax measures. He will need them should Brussels shove us into a no-deal Brexit. But that gripe aside, what was not to like The Tories must not try to ape Corbyn’s £trillion spending fantasy. But it is not “Corbyn-lite” to spend billions fixing Britain’s most pressing problems, evenwe are still running a deficit.As for Corbyn himself, it was obvious he took in barely a word of the Budget.In his “response” he merely recited his normal scripted complaints, flubbing his words and shouting randomly, as is now traditional. He somehow contrives to make even this chaotic Government look like a model of competence.Budgets often unravel when acres of small print are finally scrutinised.But for now... nice one, Chancellor.ANGELA Merkel is a once-brilliant politician scuppered by an arrogant disregard for voters.For years she was admired worldwide. Then she flooded Germany with a million migrants, enraging the public, fuelling extremism and sealing her own downfall.Don’t expect Brussels to learn from it.Their contempt for citizens is even worse. And it will do for them too.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: woman ghost face photograph abandoned house
story: Kristie Ranieri, , was on a walk with husband Michael Sharf, , when they passed the dilapidated building in Lake Forest, Illinois, and stopped to take a look.It was the summer home of socialite Ginevra King, who had a two-year romance with author F Scott Fitzgerald and was his inspiration for The Great Gatsby.Kristie, of Lake Forest, says her husband spotted the apparent apparition of a female face when flicking through their pictures later that evening.The personal chef is convinced that the image of a woman staring out of the dormer window proves the socialite, who passed away in , haunts her former family estate.Kristie said: “I visit the house every year but I skipped it last year because it had been abandoned and had really gone to pot.“But this year, with the fall colours looking so beautul, I walked around it with my husband and took some pictures.“Michael was going through the pictures that night, zooming into the windows to seehe could see the interiors and that’s when he spotted her face.“We definitely got chills. Neither of us believed in ghosts but we were really freaked out.“I knew what Ginevra King looked like because I’m interested in local history and she grew up in this area.When I saw that picture, I immediately Googled her and we both agreed it has to be her.”The couple even ed to the -room mansion, built in , the next day to seethe face was still there.Kristie said: “We rushed back to seewe could spot her again but of course she was gone.”She now hopes to approach experts who evaluate pictures of the paranormal.She said: “I want to talk to some experts in this field and I want to let the local ghost hunters know.I imagine this will now become a spot on the ghost hunting trail.“I was a sceptic before but seeing that image, I know that it is her ghost looking down.”The mansion used to be part of the -acre estate that the King Family used as a summer home and called Kingdom Come Farm.It was sold to a developer in  who hopes to find a buyer for the home which has stood uninhabited for almost a decade.Fitzgerald visited King at the home in the summers of  and  but Ginevra broke off their romance in .The following year she married William Mitchell, the son of her father Charles G King’s business associate.Fitzgerald never forgot the slight and went on to model the character of Daisy Buchanan, Gatsby’s unattainable love interest, in his famous  novel on King.Ginevras father reportedly told Fitzgerald: “Poor boys shouldn’t think of marrying rich girls.”Although Fitzgerald did not include the line in his famous novel, it found its way into the  film adaptation of The Great Gatsby starring Mia Farrow and Robert Redford.

title: prince harry offers student job new zealand
story: Lucia Kennedy chatted to the Duke and Duchess of Sussex during an event at a café in Wellington focusing on youth mental health on Monday.The -year-old, who is studying a double degree in commerce and psychology at university, told Stuff: I said to Harry, I finish uni in two years, Id love to come and work for you.He said, Wed love to have you, just give us a yell when you come over, well sort it out.The student said shed celebrate the job offer by having dinner with her flatmates.Lucia, who describes herself as a happiness entrepreneur, was part of a  minute session at the Maranui cafe to discuss youth mental health.She founded the Take A Chance Project, which offers coaching and mentor programmes for young people, after losing friends and her family home in the Christchurch earthquake when she was just .Lucia said: I saw Harrys face light up when he heard about counselling offered to the defence team and New Zealand military personnel.He was really impressed and happy to hear that, I think.During his time at the cafe, Harry spoke about his own struggles with mental health admitting that it took him years to confront his own inner turmoil after losing his mum Diana, Princess of Wales, in a car crash aged .He said: It took me about three or four years to start the journey and then after that you still have to find the right people to speak to.Harry praised Voices of Hope for their  viral video Dear Suicidal Me, which features young people who have overcome mental health issues reading their own suicide notes.The couple heard the video saved the le of a -year-old young girl in Canada.Her mother contacted us and said that her daughter was planning to take her le but then saw the video and went to speak to her instead, said Jazz Thornton, co-founder of Voices of Hope.It saved her le.Harry said: Its amazing what you have done.I think anyone who has overcome mental health problems often go out of their own way to help others.

title: businesswoman caught swerving all over the road when double the alcohol limit told cops she didnt know her colleagues had been topping up her drink on works night out
story: Rachel Hind, , was stopped by cops when they saw her Audi A swerving onto the wrong side of the road after she left an Italian restaurant.Hind had just treated  colleagues to dinner, but on her way home at am police officers had to take evasive action in their patrol van to avoid hitting Hinds car.When whey asked her to get out of her car, the registered nurse struggled to get her keys out of the ignition.She was also staggering in her high heels with slurred speech, glazed eyes and her breath smelling heavily of alcohol, the court heard.It emerged the mum-of-two had been drinking Prosecco, gin and tonic and double vodkas with cola during one of her regular evenings out to thank their employees before heading to her £.million home in High Legh, near Knutsford, Cheshire.At Manchester Magistrates Court Hind admitted drink driving but tried to argue against disqualication claiming she thought she was sober at the time.She added that she did not realise a colleague had unwittingly topped up her drinks throughout the evening in the belief she was getting a taxi home.She claimed she was only swerving around in the road as she was attempting to avoid potholes. JPs banned her for  months and fined her £, with costs of £.The incident occurred at .am on June  this year after Hind had left the Italian Job restaurant in Urmston after the party had spent up to six hours eating and drinking.John Richards prosecuting said: The police evidence says she was swerving around.She was unsteady on her feet, her eyes were glazed and her speech was slurred. She was staggering and her breath stank of alcohol and she needed help into the police van.The crown say it would have been patently obvious to her that she was over the limit. You might think it’s strange that she didn’t realise her Prosecco had been topped up. In a short period of time, the glass goes from half full to full - how did she not realise that In terms of the vodka and cola, evenit was the case that you’re dealing with single shots, you’re going to knowit’s got alcohol in it. But we are talking about doubles here. The crown says that it doesn’t stack up that she didn’t realise.Tests showed Hind, who specialises in end-of-le care at her two care homes, blew a reading of  microgrammes of alcohol in  millilitres of breath. The legal limit is mg.She told the hearing: Every quarter of the year I take the staff out for a meal and drinks and to say thank you. I take them to an Italian restaurant and they have an open bar. I just pay the bill and let them have what they want.I would always drive there and drive home. Very occasionally, I would get a taxi but on that day I drove. I was on call that night which means I am in charge of running the night sht. I ordered a single gin and tonic.I always would have a gin and tonic and maybe a glass of ProseccoI was having a three-course meal.She added: There were jugs of water all along the table which I had some of. I also had about four to five glasses of coke and I also had a glass of Prosecco with my main meal which was at about ish. I felt fine. I didn’t feel drunk, I felt fine to drive - I didn’t think I was taking a risk. I gave my colleague a lt home, which I wouldn’t have doneI felt drunk.But the road was full of potholes. It did occur to me that I hope the police don’t think I am a drunk driver because I am swerving to avoid the potholes. I have had four punctures in two years on that car from potholes.But I didn’t think I caused the police van to swerve. The police woman told me to open my car and I told her that I needed to shut the car door to turn off the engine - I did struggle to get the car keys out when I did this.I told the officer from the very beginning that I had been drinking, but it was only one gin and tonic and a glass of Prosecco over the course of a three course meal. I struggled out of the police van, but I was wearing high heels and I don’t normally wear them.I had a terrible row with my husband about it afterwards. I was disappointed in myself and I went into a spell of depression. I couldn’t tell anybody at work about it because I am their employer and I am supposed to be an example to them.She claimed a colleague Amanda Jackson later confessed to topping up her drinks during the evening during a heart-to-heart meeting and added: She went white in the face and said ‘I’m sorry, but I topped your drinks up that night.’She didn’t know I was driving home and she told me that she had been giving me drinks. She said she topped up my Prosecco once and that she had put Vodka and Cokes on the table.If I am drinking alcohol, it’s only gin and tonic that I am drinking which I know the smell and taste of. I don’t drink vodka. I have never been a vodka and cola - it just tasted of cola.Retrospectively, I can see now that I was drunk but at no point did I feel over the limit at the time, I was talking to my colleague all the way home in the car.My cousin died after being hit by an articulated lorry and my best friends nephew was also hit by a drunk driver. I haven’t drink driven until this incident where I unknowingly got into my car while over the limit and drove.Work colleague Miss Jackson admitted unwittingly getting doubles for her boss.She said: I made sure that the drinks and food were going to the right people. I went to the bar a couple of times and ordered about four vodka and cokes each time and I just brought them to the table and put them down there.I saw she was drinking coke but I didn’t realise she was supposed to be drinking normal coke.I was just going around the table filling the glasses up. I filled them all up.When she told me what happened I said ‘Oh my god, I am so sorry I bought you some drinks and I didn’t know you weren’t drinking.’It’s all my fault and she’s in all this trouble and I didn’t know she wasn’t drinking. She is my boss and she is amazing at what she does, and I feel terrible and will take the consequences.I am not going to lie, I was quite drunk that night - about a  .”Hinds lawyer Miss Stephanie Varle said: “In the UK, a lot of people drink a small amount of alcohol and drive.You have heard that she reasonably believed that she drank a gin and tonic and a glass of Prosecco and was safe to drive home. She did go out and consume some alcohol, which the law permits her to do - but she didn’t notice her drink had been topped up.This is a woman who works  hours and was on call on that evening. I submit that when she was moving around, she would not notice an odourless drink. She was driving at a normal speed and was simply trying to circumnavigate the potholes in the road.The alcohol limit does unfortunately permit people to lawfully get behind the wheel of a car after some drink.But JP Edward Tasker, said: Having heard all the evidence, we don’t accept that the defendant didn’t know that the drinks didn’t have alcohol in them.

title: giant rat invasion foot long bristol
story: The woman, who asked not to be named, spotted the giant rodents scurrying along her turfed balcony in the Lockleaze area of Bristol.The mum said the first-floor balcony of her housing association home had become infested along with neighbours properties.She told the Bristol Post: Something needs to be done to cure this problem for good.They have chewed threw the walls of the building to get across to each property.My children have noticed them but theyre a bit young to understand.Bristol-based United Communities housing association said the entire city has been suffering from rat infestations.Jayme Whittleson, control manager at the housing association, said: This was first reported to us on Facebook and straight away we attended.The bins were in a very reasonable order, they werent over-flowing.Rats are an issue all over the city.This summers heatwave brought a plague of giant rats across the UK.The disease-ridden rodents can grow up to four feet long - twice the size of a typical house cat.Experts say there could now be as many as  million rats across Britain.We pay for your stories! title: the 2018 budget our experts verdicts
story: THE ECONOMYEd Conway, economics editorAt first glance, this budget was a far bigger deal than many people had been expecting.In fact, look at the simple numbers and this was one of the biggest giveaway budgets ever - though thats almost entirely because of the extra #bn being spent on the NHS.But how did the chancellor find that cash  The short answer is almost entirely through extra borrowing.Earlier this year, the public finances improved dramatically, as more tax receipts started to flood into the Exchequer.But rather than put that money in his pocket, using it to pay off the national debt, the chancellor decided, instead, to spend it. That was a big sht. In hindsight, however, it was hardly surprising.Philip Hammond needed as much money as he could get his hands on to both increase departmental spendingand to fund the giveaways previously announced by the prime minister, most notably the extra NHS spending.And thats before one gets to the rabbit out of his hat: increasing the tax-free personal allowance a year early.Is austerity really coming to an end  It depends how you measure it.If you ignore the NHS, per-capita spending cuts are due to continue in the coming years - albeit gradually.Include the NHS, and it certainly looks like austerity is over.Either way, the pace of cuts has reduced considerably - all at the cost, though, of higher borrowing and public finances that remain very weak.Indeed, the chancellors pledge to eliminate the budget deficit by the middle of the next decade has been well and truly broken, according to the Office for Budget Responsibility.The politics was as interesting as the economics.An end to austerity , abolishing PFI, introducing a tax on tech giants, putting billions into the benefits system and, most of all, the decision to spend rather than save the extra windfall in the public finances.One can hardly imagine previous Conservative chancellors doing that - but that is precisely what this government has done.Its hard to believe it was a Conservative budget. POLITICSBeth Rigby, deputy political editor Phillip Hammond said his was a budget for the "grafters and strivers" who get up early and go to work - as he tried to use his statement to assure them that "their hard work is paying off and the era of austerity is coming to an end".And he put his money where his mouth was, as he brought promised tax cuts for  million people forward by a year.The personal tax allowance is being lted to #, in April , while the level at which the higher rate of tax kicks in will also be raised to #, a year.Those cuts brought him cheers in the chamber, but when it came to wider public spending, it was a jam tomorrow budget for a chancellor boxed in by the economic uncertainty of Brexit. Fiscally, it is dficult to calculate how much the public finances will be affected by Brexit when we still dont knowthe UK will be leaving with a deal or not.There was a bit of extra money for social care , for defence , for schoolsand for potholes and road repairs .In reality, however, the big spending decisions will come next year in a post-Brexit spending review for the whole of Whitehall.But Mr Hammond did find money for Universal Credit to reverse swingeing cuts for Britains lowest earners, promising an extra #bn over the next five years to help ameliorate the worst effects of shting from the old benefits system to the new one.That was well below what some Conservative MPs had been demanding, though.Against the backdrop of Brexit, Mr Hammond was pretty constrained.Ending austerity is a post-Brexit project - and the current incumbents of No  and No  Downing Street may well not be the pair wholl end up delivering it. BUSINESSIan King, business presenterThere were some welcome announcements for business.Entrepreneurs relief, which some had expected to get the chop, lives for another day but the minimum qualying period will be extended from one year to two years to ensure it does genuinely work as intended.Small businesses dodged a bullet when the threshold at which VAT becomes payable was kept at #, for the next two years. Many had expected it to be lowered.There were also tweaks to the use by large private companies of private contractors to avoid paying national insurance. These measures have already been rolled out for the public sector.Then came the much-touted assault on the US tech giants.Digital s "pose a real challenge to the sustainability and fairness of our tax system", said Mr Hammond, highlighting the low taxes paid by the tech multinationals.

title: the last budget before brexit but a deal hasnt happened yet
story: The deficit should have been closing in on zero. Instead, it is left at a persistent #bn or so.So the government retrospectively funded the promise made by the PM for the biggest ever cash increase in NHS funding, but did so without raising taxes.In fact it cut them a bit by accelerating to this coming April, the rise in basic rate and higher rate income tax thresholds to #, and #, respectively.At the time of that announcement in summer, even at the Conservative Party conference, the Chancellor had suggested that these spending rises would be at least partly funded by tax rises.Not so, according to these numbers. But they may yet materialise on the other side of the Brexit fog.In that respect - the extra spending on the NHS, not funded by a tax rise - there was an end to austerity politics. But Mr Hammond was pointed in claiming austerity was coming to an end, rather than actually over. The government has calculated that there is no prize for a cash surplus.The claim about austerity itself was more debatable.The expected "fiscal envelope" for the spending review was conspicuous by its absence. It will be decided next year, though indicative figures were given. story: News nasty surprises in the Budget small print that the Tories wont want you to readAs always, the devil is in the detail. Heres what weve found in the small printShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorMikey SmithPolitical reporterNicola BartlettDan Bloom:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video budget--the-key-points-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMore money for schools, the NHS and Universal Credit were among the eye-catching announcements in Philip Hammonds budget speech today. But as always, the devils in the detail. Once you get past the bad jokes, the shiny baubles and the claims that austerity is over - all thats left is the small print. And guess what  Some of it will leave you and your family worse off. Weve trawled through all  pages of the Budget Red Book, plus the independent Office of Budget Responsibility s assessment of the measures in it. Heres a few things you might not have spotted.  A chart buried in the small print shows how the Budget won’t actually make the poorest % any better off. This diagram shows the cumulative impact of ALL tax, welfare and public service changes since  - a mammoth task. Look at it - the poorest people are on the left, and they simply flatline in the analysis. While the richest % are taking a hit, it’s middle-class people - those in the top % or % - who will benefit the most, gaining up to pound a year.  Philip Hammond made a big play of pumping more money into defence and the NHS. But he was a little quieter about yet more swingeing cuts being forced on some of the biggest frontline Whitehall departments. The Department for Work and Pensions is being expected to cut its budget from poundbn to pound.bn in   . The Ministry of Justice is being cut from pound.bn to poundbn. And the housing and communities section of Whitehall is being cut from pound.bn to pound.bn. That’s despite a welfare crisis, a prisons crisis and a housing crisis. Why are they doing this  . That plastic tax will take FOUR YEARS to come in  Chancellor Philip Hammond claimed he’d become a world leader in tackling the scourge of plastic littering our planet.” He might have to do a bit better then. Not only did he resist any call to tax plastic cups. His big signature move - a tax on packaging that doesn’t have at least % recycled plastic - will only come in April . He made no mention of the date in his speech - we had to find it in the small print. Environmental Audit Committee chair Mary Creagh blasted: This speaks volumes about the Treasury’s priorities. As China, Vietnam and Thailand close their doors on Britain’s plastic waste the chancellors response is keep calm and carry on.”  According to the OBR forecast Google and other online giants could pay a mere poundm each under Hammonds new tax. Labour said the figure was “a pittance for these massive international companies” They said the percentage of tax paid by the big five tech giants had halved since . The new tax won’t come into force until  at which time the tech giants will start to enjoy a % cut in their corporation tax rate. Tom Watson, shadow Secretary of State for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport, said: “The lack of ambition in this announcement is derisory.” . … And it raises even less than we thought  If you thought the poundm raised from the Digital Services Tax didn’t seem like much, then don’t look at the back of the Budget book. It shows poundm a year is only what it’ll raise in . Next year it raises…. poundmillion. And in   it only raises poundmillion. . Crack cocaine of gambling stakes will stay above pound for another year  Campaigners blasted a six-month delay to cutting stakes on fixed-odds betting terminalsto pound. The move to slash maximum stakes on the “crack cocaine of gambling” from pound had been expected to come into force next April. But the Budget small print revealed the move will not take place until October. The Campaign for Fairer Gambling said it was “unacceptable”. Labour’s Carolyn Harris, who chairs Parliament’s cross-party group on FOBTs, was “appalled” at the “wholly unjustiable” delay. But a Treasury source said: “It’s clearly a judgement call. This we think strikes the right balance.”  Hammond announced an extra pound million for struggling schools to pay for “the little extras” they can’t afford. Many parents will have breathed a sigh of relief at the news, after getting begging letters from their kids’ teachers, asking for money to pay for such extravagances as pens, books and toilet paper. But they’ll be disappointed. The money is “capital spending”, ringfenced for building maintenance and purchasing equipment. That means schools will be allowed to buy iPads with the extra cash, but not pens and paper.  The Sovereign Grant - the money paid by the government to support the Queen in her royal duties is going up. Again. Last year the figure was .m - this year it’ll go up to an eye-watering pound. million. The size of the grant is usually % of the government’s income from Crown Estates. But last year she got a  year boost to % to pay for essential refurbishment of Buckingham Palace.  The government is set to introduce a tax on vaping for the first time. So-called heated tobacco products will be taxed at the same rate as hand rolling tobacco from April . Duty on rolling tobacco amounts to around pound for the smallest, g packs. Its unclear how this would translate to vape fluid, which is measured in millilitres, or whether there would be a minimum level of duty.  Tory ministers have finally admitted they’re delaying Universal Credit, the small print reveals. The rollout of the hated six-in-one benefit will officially end in December  - the ninth delay after its last end date of March . And it may only finish in June , because the Office for Budget Responsibility “assumes” it will take six months longer than the Department for Work and Pensionssays. Just weeks ago, the DWP was refusing to confirm any delay to the Mirror. Delaying the rollout will actually save the DWP poundbillion - because thanks to a pound.bn-a-year package of help, it’s now “more expensive than the legacy system would have been”, the OBR declared. There’s also a suggestion that the money will be saved because, by delaying UC, less will be handed over to claimants in transition payments.  The Office For Budget Responsibility admits No Deal Brexit will have a “severe” impact. “If an agreement is not reached in time, it could have a severe short-term impact on demand and supply in the economy,” it says. “It is next to impossible to calibrate this sort of scenario because of the lack of precedent.” Philip Hammond announced another poundmillion in no-deal Brexit preparations, taking the total to pound.billion. The Chancellor boasted of “firepower to intervene”the economy needs more support in coming months - with poundbillion of “headroom” to deploy. Labour’s Chris Leslie, of the People’s Vote campaign, claimed: “There is no Brexit idend, only years of extended pain.” . … And the Brexit orce bill may have hit poundbillion  Again, this is one from the independent OBR, not the Budget document itself. The experts forecast that the Brexit orce bill could hit poundbn, much higher than the poundbn the government has claimed. It’s been revised up because of a weaker pound-euro exchange rate, and changes to contribution formulas and timetables. Best for Britain chief Eloise Todd said: Far from the fantasy millions promised by Brexiters, it has become increasingly clear that Britain will be facing a Brexit deficit.” . A controversial Tory home buying scheme is being reopened, and it’s costing poundbillion  You’d think a package of help for first-time buyers costing almost poundbillion might have been mentioned in the Budget speech. But nope - you have to delve into the documents to find the Help to Buy equity loan scheme is being reopened for two years from April . The scheme was previously slammed for helping buyers who were already well-off and allowing a five-year “time bomb” of fees to build up. This time it will be available only to first-time buyers - correcting a major flaw in the old scheme - but there are still some elements of unfairness. Londoners will be able to use it to get a home worth pound,, while in the North East it’s only available on homes worth pound,. And the scheme’s enormous cost on its own will attract attention.  We’ve found this one not in the Budget itself, but the report from the Office for Budget Responsibility. It says capital spending - long-term one-off hits on building projects and the like - has been cut, and the Treasury hasn’t spelt it out. The OBR says: “Departmental capital spending has also been cut from - onwards, a decision that does not appear on the Treasury’s scorecard of policy measures.”

story: NewsopinionJohn McDonnell: Philip Hammond gave a broken promise budget, failing to end austerityBy choosing to cut rather than invest, Tories have failed to fix the weaknesses of the economy, says the Shadow ChancellorShareCommentsByJohn McDonnellShadow Chancellor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsopinion "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPeople will not put up with austerity any more, and the pressure is on Hammond to end it.But today he gave a broken-promise Budget, failing to end austerity, which was always a political choice. For more than eight years the Tories have given huge tax giveaways to the few while driving our public services into crisis. By choosing to cut rather than invest, Tories have failed to fix the weaknesses of the economy: low growth, low investment, low pay.Now, their approach to Brexit is putting it at risk. Tories have announced the end of austerity three times and never delivered. Much more is needed to start undoing the damage caused by cuts since . The poundbillion promised for the NHS is “simply not enough”, according to the independent Health Foundation, and can’t come at the expense of other public services.Local councils faces a funding gap of pound.billion by . Local services are at breaking point. School funding has been cut by %. Universal credit is pushing families into poverty. UC will leave the poorest families pound a month worse off, yet % of post- social security cuts are to come. Tories have spent more time arguing with themshyselves than negotiating with the EU. Labour will negotiate a Brexit deal that respects the referendum result whilst protecting jobs and rights at work. Labour will rebuild our economy for the many and not the few.

title: philip hammonds brexit blindness mirror
story: NewsopinionPhilip Hammonds Brexit blindness: Mirror Politics morning briefingThe Budget failed on two counts: it increased inequality and it failed to offer a bold agenda for post-Brexit BritainShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  OCT NewsopinionThe congratulations could be short lived "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email If there was a phrase which will come to define yesterday’s Budget it was Philip Hammond’s handing poundmillion for schools to buy “the little extras they need.” The Chancellor has a reputation for political deafness but this was especially insensitive. The little extras headteachers need include not having to close their schools early, not having to cancel music and swimming lessons, not having to lay off teaching assistants and not having to beg parents for items such as toilet paper and stationery. Hammond’s choice of words pointed to a deeper problem. It implied that teachers and parents should be grateful for his largesse. But when you have put someone in hospital, you should not be surprisedthe patient then takes umbrageyou come round with a bunch of grapes and words of comfort. The Resolution Foundation think tank delivered its verdict on the Budget this morning and found it was deeply regressive. The Tories like to spin the raising of the income tax threshold as evidence of how they are helping the just about managing but it is a tax cut which is skewed towards the better off and does nothing for the five million people who earn too little to pay the tax.According to the Resolution Foundation, % of the income tax cuts announced yesterday will go to the top half of earners. The richest tenth of households are set to gain  times as much in cash terms next year from the income tax and benefits giveaways in the Budget as the poorest tenth of households . The small print tells a dferent narrative to that presented by the Chancellor. Once you strip away the increase in NHS spending then there is almost nothing for other departments. Even the extra pound.billion for the universal credit is offset by the poundbillion of welfare cuts being imposed by the Tories. Hammond framed his Budget as an example of how the Conservatives were balancing the ending of austerity with continued fiscal discipline. This was a sleight of hand when the figures show the strictures will remain in place for several years to come. The giveaways masked a bigger issue: the Chancellor has limited room to manoeuvre until Brexit is resolved. Everything is predicated upon Theresa May securing a deal.

story: NewsHundreds queue in street to see incredible secret paintings discovered in pensioners home after he diedEric Tuckers massive painting collection was discovered by relatives in Warrington, Cheshire when they went to clear out his home after he died at the age of ShareCommentsByPhoebe Jobling:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video erik-tuckers-brother-says-no-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailUnskilled labourer Eric Tucker left a secret unseen legacy of artworks worthy of LS Lowry when he died at the home he lived in for virtually all his le. Unbeknown to his family, the ex-boxer who left school at  without qualication braved arthritis to create  oil and water colours in his front room over a seven decade period depicting working class le in his hometown. Rather than offering them for sale or exhibition, Eric kept his works out of public view - and instead stacked them around his unassuming end terraced property including his airing cupboard, in his shed and on top of his wardrobes. The massive painting collection was only discovered by relatives after the bachelor who lived alone in Warrington, Cheshire passed away last July aged  and they went to clear out his home.  Most of the pictures feature Lowry-type scenes from smoky pubs, tumbledown terraced streets and factories and showing flat capped locals with their wives. There are also several paintings of clowns, following on from Eric’s love of the circus as a child and portraits of his parents. Now Erics former home is to temporarily turned into a free art gallery for one weekend only which will display  of his paintings in an exhibition entitled  Years of Unseen Art. Younger brother Tony, , said: We did know Eric had a passion for art but never realised he had hoarded a huge collection in his home. He was a very modest man who never talked up his skills and despite doing sketches in his local he appeared to everyone just to be an ordinary Joe.  “Now all of the family have been wonderful, and we’ve all worked together in the hope that we will do justice to Erics work justice and get him the recognition he so richly deserves. We’re just sad that he isnt alive to see this all happen.” Eric the oldest of three children was born at the property in  and left school in  when he was just . He took up boxing and served four years in the Royal Horse Guards in Germany before working for local building contractors Arthur Monk in Warrington. His brother added: Eric didn’t do very well at school. He didn’t like being organised or people telling him what to do but he was intelligent and creative. He was known for having a love of boxing but he also had a passion for art too, “Despite having arthritis for most of his le, he never stopped painting. I’d call round to the house and find him painting on the front parlour. He never had any art training, but he was very committed. He was very modest. Painting wasn’t a hobby, it was his le.” Eric often drank in local pubs and working mens clubs and his paintings were often based on barroom scenes. Tony added: “Whenever he was in the pub, he would sketch on scraps of paper, drawing people in pubs across Warrington and Manchester. He especially loved Manchester in the s.  “Eric was a socialist and felt the most comfortable around ordinary working people and that they had the richest lives. He believed that people should always look out for one another. He had no formal art training beyond a sign writing apprenticeship but his knowledge and appreciation of painting was extensive – and his opinions on the subject were totally valid. He did get some offers to exhibit or buy his work but for some reason he refused as he did not want his paintings given away. Sadly his arthritis eventually prevented him from holding a paint brush but he did say he wanted his paintings to be seen after he was gone. We just assumed it would be a few pieces - but not . They were stacked up all around his house in his shed and on top of wardrobes. Im sure he will be delighted to learn his work will get a great deal of recognition. The exhibition will open from October  to  at Erics home Number , King George Crescent, Warrington, WA SH.

The Duke and Duchess of Sussex joined a group of children to see who could throw their boots the furthest to kick off the th day of their Royal Tour. It started to rain just as they arrived in Redvale, North Shore to dedicate a -hectare area of native bush to the Queens Commonwealth Canopy, but that didnt stop them getting involved in the fun. Harry threw first with a blue and yellow spotted welly for his yellow team: two pupils from Pinehill Primary School. Meghan was the last to throw from her red team and they were lagging behind Harrys yellow. Cheered on by the pupils shouting Go Meghan, she tossed the red and white spotted boot high into the air-even surprising herself at how far it went.  Her throw clinched it for her team and they were awarded the gumboot throwing competition trophy. Ryen Anderson, , who was on her team said: “Meghan was asking us how to throw and we said it doesn’t matter. “She didn’t know she could throw that far and she surprised herself. “She was really pleased we’d won and said next time we’ll have to do another one and Harry said next time ‘we’ll win’!” The couple arrived at north shore riding club after they’d flown from Wellington to Auckland in a RNZAF jet. Looking causal in a Karen Walker blazer and J Crew Jeans, Harry and Meghan had barely sat down in an open paddock before the heavens opened with torrential rain. They had been driven through some of the  hectares of native bush that the riding club had dedicated before they arrived for a welcome ceremony. Kaumata Joe Harawira led the formal welcomeafter the karainga had called the couple forward and they took their seats on white plastic chairs. James Guild, chairman of the QEII trust, equivalent of the UK’s National Trust and responsible for the QCC in New Zealand, have a lovely speech welcoming the couple and congratulating them on their forthcoming baby. “Perhaps some time in the future we will see Her Majesty’s great-grandchild back in Mew Zealand to check up on the covenant dedicated by his or her parents on their first trip to New Zealand together.” President of the Riding Club Adrianne Deeley proposed a round of applause for local campaigner Carole Whaley, after whom the forest was named. And she raised some laughs with her comments about her horse Harry.  She said: “I would have liked my harry to meet harry but I checked on his schedule and it’s pretty tight. It’ll have to be another time!”Harry then took to the stage and raised cheers with “my we and I...” He said: “The Queen’s Commonwealth Canopy – or QCC - is a unique network of forest conservation projects. “It was launched in , to mark my grandmothers long service to the Commonwealth and is an initiative that is dear to her heart – and now to mine. “As of last week,  out of the  Commonwealth countries have signed up to the QCC, with Kiribati being the most recent addition. “New Zealand was one of the first countries to join. And it has also shown great leadership in this area, inspiring other countries to follow, and leading by example. “It is fitting that New Zealand’s contribution to the Canopy has been through its relationship with the QEII National Trust. The Trust was set up to mark the Queen’s Silver Jubilee in . Since then, nearly four and a half thousand covenants have been registered through the Trust.”  After his speech, Harry and Meghan were invited to unveil the QCC plaque and plant two trees. Duchess Meghan planted a New Zealand kōwhai tree, which is one of the distinctive Kiwi flowers  chosen to represent the country embroidered on her wedding veil. Harry planted a puriri tree which can grow up up to m tall. Alex Chatterton, , from Pinehill Primary school said: “I planted a tree with Meghan. She asked me why I do this and told us to get started. “She was v good at first. “She said ‘oh do you want gloves’ but I don’t need them! They were nice caring and let you do whatever you want. “It was fun.” Meghan said to him: “I’ll shake your hands buddy! Doesn’t matter they’re dirty.”  Then it was onto the welly-wanging. Isabella Iti, , said: “She’s really pretty and stands for women’s rights. Our teachers have told us a lot about what she does and how she helps people. “It was important to plant trees as it helps the earth as trees give us oxygen and homes for native birds.“Meghan asked us what our favourite subjects was and Harry told jokes. “He tried to out the gloves [to plant the trees] but then chucked them off. He was good at planting the tree. The two teams were really trying. I think Harry and Meghan are quite competitive as they looked like they were REALLY trying to throw the gumboot as far as they could.  They did really good, particularly Meghan. I think Meghan was thinking there was no chance she could win but she did!!” Chairman of the QEII trust James guild,  said: “They are a very happy couple at the end of a long trip. I asked the duchessshe was tired and she said she wasn’t! She said she’d been misquoted! “We gave them four presents. “A mini pair of gumbouts for a three year old green with painted kiwis. “A baby shawl or pure New Zealand wool. Pounamu nz green stone on a chain and we actually put them on.“They were extremely grateful and they said they would be very useful. The duchess thought the gumboots were very cute. “Harry takes a farmer’s perspective with rain. He said it was a blessing. He gets so annoyed when people complain about the rain asit’s so important.”
